text:
I have a bunch of blog posts that are in the following folder format

```content
├── 00.md
├── 01.md
├── 02.md```
But they are rendered on my current blog as:

```<http://website.com/unique-name-for-00.html|website.com/unique-name-for-00.html>
<http://website.com/unique-name-for-01.html|website.com/unique-name-for-01.html>
<http://website.com/unique-name-for-02.html|website.com/unique-name-for-02.html>```
I have two questions:

1) I believe I can create a `@url = unique-name-for-00` inside each file and that'll handle the name of the url. Is my understanding correct? Is this the recommended way of doing this?
2) Currently, I believe the url will still be `<http://website.com/content/unique-name-for-dd.html|website.com/content/unique-name-for-dd.html>`. Is there a way to remove the `content` from the final `__site` folder structure, but preserve it in the source markdown folder?

text:
you can create `redirect` easily which is probably the most straightforward way to go for whatever desired URL you may want.

For this just write

```{{redirect bar/foo/baz.html}}```
in the `.md` file (at the top or whatever, doesn't matter), this will mean that the page you currently have will also be available at `<http://website.com/prepath/bar/foo/baz.html|website.com/prepath/bar/foo/baz.html>`

if what you want is rather to keep your file structure and modify the produced file naming so that the URL of `00.md` is available at  `what-i-want-00/` *and* that the URL that appears is `what-i-want-00` then this is not supported. Feel free to open an issue about it.
